Thanks Herald, even I don't think it is a junit problem .I tried 
with a new build but the problem persists.

I am confused in the approach I should take to test the application
 one being should I consider the unit test case as a client which 
invokes the session bean from outside the server container(in which 
case extending the testcase will be the solution)
 or the other being use cactus to create test cases (extend 
ServletTestCase)which runs within the server container.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Harald M. Muller 
<harald.m.mueller@b...> wrote:
> 
> >     I have junit test case which checks a create user method in 
a 
> > userproxy class which internally invokes a session bean 
> [...]
> > Bean.javax.naming.NoInitialContextException: Need to specify 
class 
> > name in environment or system property, or as an applet 
parameter, 
> > or in an application resource file:  java.naming.factory.i
> > nitial : 
> 
> This is not really a unit test problem:
> 
> Your test is a client which has to create an InitialContext to 
find the
> home interface (presumably) - like any EJB client. In such a case, 
it is
> necessary to define the initial context factory - see any EJB book 
or
> documentation!
> Usually, you have to provide those two:
> 
> * java.naming.factory.initial
> * java.naming.provider.url
> 
> Here is an example for a client of an JBoss appserver using -D:
> 
> -
Djava.naming.factory.initial=org.jnp.interfaces.NamingContextFactory
> -Djava.naming.provider.url=jnp://localhost:1099 
> 
> For other possibilities, see the documentation of your appserver.
> 
> Regards
> Harald M.
